dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK RUSSELL and his 18-year-old son, GEORGE, crouch in a makeshift cattail blind. Roosting ducks are dropping into the marsh. on the water floats an arrangement of duck decoys which have lured the ducks to the pond. In the blind, Jack holds a long-barrel, semi-automatic shotgun. George mans a sealed-beam car-light hooked to a portable car battery. The light is not yet shining. Jack peeks through at the ducks while George keeps his head do checking and retwisting the connections to the battery. It’s mid-June on the northern Montana Hi-line, and it’s chilly as the sky barely lightens eastward. The ducks : settle and the marsh goes quiet. Jack, in the blind, take _a long, deep breath, squeezes off the safety of his shot regards his son beside hin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Shine, George. Shine now. George clicks the crude switch on the car-light and the yellow beam streams out onto the marsh surface through th cattails. The ducks are there, all of them on the water, completely exposed and not yet alarmed by the light. Jack stands and begins shooting down on the water with the shotgun, methodical shooting, not fast, but gauged to cov as much of the water as he can. Most of the ducks are hit sitting in the water, but some fall just as they begin to lift off. Jack shoots, in all, eleven times. On the water after the last gun blast, there are 54 ducks dead or dyin

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (quietly) Well. There’s that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: . JACK
dialogues.text: A lot of ‘em. A lot of ‘em that time. Good work on the light, George. You were steady as a rock. Jack and George begin to wade into the marsh to collect t ' @ucks floating there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack drives his truck up to a local meat locker/slaughter house, HONKS his horn. The LOCKER OWNER walks out while George grabs sacks of ducks from under a tarp in the truc cab. Jack stays behind the wheel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER OWNER
dialogues.text: (to Jack) How many?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Forty-three Mallards. . Mostly green~heads.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER OWNER
dialogues.text: Did you see any game wardens out there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (sarcastic, smiling) Saw a hundred of ‘em. They just didn’t see me. The Locker Owner begins to count out cash from his pocket into Jack’s hand. George sees the transaction as he walks with the sacks toward the slaughterhouse.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER OWNER
dialogues.text: (counting) How’s the railroad, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Mean and lean. Pay’s regular.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 4 INT./EXT. GRAIN ELEVATOR/ Broadview- AFTERNOON George finishes a hot, airless job cleaning the inside of elevator which has just been emptied. He is sweaty and dusty. He exits, goes inside an airless little washroom, washes his hands and face. He exits the silo, starts walk toward town. 5 EXT. POLAR BAR/ Broadview AFTERNOON George crosses street and enters Polar Bar. Sunburst is a tiny, grain-elevator town built on the Grea Northern Railway, twenty miles south of the Alberta borde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is convivial and peopled by a few farmers and railroad crewmen, a country bar with a few poker, keno (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: machines, high school football schedules tacked to the ba bar walls. Jack sits at the bar smoking a cigarette over his beer an whiskey. He is a railroad brakeman, 44, a tough, soft- spoken man whose life has dropped him in a place he might not have planned, but that he’s made accommodations for. He’s mildly drunk. George loads nickels into one of the poker machines again the walls, hitting the buttons, while one of the older ba habitues, slightly drunk watches him from the nert, machi

dialogues.speaker: BAR HABITUE
dialogues.text: Ace George! . Jesus you can't : win this game. This game's rigged against you. You better quit. (Laughs. ) . George gives the machine a hard shove and a kick. He turn glances at his father at the bar. A MAN--a fellow railroader--is huddled with Jack, talking seriously. Thei conversation can’t be heard. The man puts his arm on Jack back, says another ardent word, then walks out of the bar George turns away from the poker machine and walks to whe Jack is sitting at the bar. Jack is moody, as if he’s hea bad news.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What’s happening? The BARTENDER drifts past Jack’s empty glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Ready for another one, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (ignoring him, to George) Let’s get out of the bar. Okay? I saved back three quackers. [711 grill ‘em. Do something different. Surprise your mother.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (uneasy) Good. That’1l make her happy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack takes a painful pinch of George’s belly, using his h grip.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: you can’t box on dead legs. You gonna make your weight? -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It'd actually be nice to come ina little over. That’s the way you win.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (patiently) Ican’t. You can’t do that anymore. CLAUDE PHILLIPS enters the bar and motions to George from the door. Claude is 19, dark, black-haired and good- looking, a full-blooded Blackfeet Indian who looks more Latin than Indian. He’s a wild boy, already sophisticated with girls, whereas George is less savvy, more home-turni but restless for some kind of action.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: (to George) . Come here. I wanna show you something. George walks to his father, who’s obviously on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’m, uh, going outside with Claude just for a minute. I/11 be right back. Jack looks skeptically across the bar at Claude.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t fuck around. Okay. I’m not stayin’ long.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I won't. I-promise. : Jack makes a pistol gesture at Claude, who smiles roguish back. He and George exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something is clearly up with Claude. He’s in high spirits They walk, hurrying toward Claude’s car, a ‘72 Chevy junk which is across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Get in the car with me, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Sherman’s got a woman with him out at the motel, which is typical. He dead-headed her in from Havre last night. .Now he wants out of it. So who does he call? His son. I’m going to get him out of it. It oughta be funny. I guess you don’t want to see it, though.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’ll see it. I’d like to have a look at it. They enter the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude produces a half-pint vodka bottle from under the visor, and they each take a drink.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Sherman forgets where he hides it. Claude laughs, takes a drink, gives the bottle over to George. : .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Rocket fuel!

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Fire up your missile. They drive out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sonic Motel is a little cottage camp with 6 units and skinny gravel lot. Claude drives in behind the pickup and HONKS his horn. George looks at the office cabin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A woman--the MANAGER--is standing in the doorway watching A 7-year-old child is playing in front of the office in t dust. After a moment, the cabin door opens and SHERMAN PHILLIPS steps outside, closes the door behind him and wa to Claude’s car. sie. GEORGE What does your mother think about this?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: She married a gash hound. Here comes the great lady’s man. The big Indian. Claude revs the engine. Sherman is a large, dark Indian with a big, tight belly. He wears glasses and is in his socks and has on a long-sleeved white shirt. His hair is tied in a long ponytail. CLAUDE (CONT’D) Clear conscience is no conscience.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: You two’re drunk as monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: No, we're not drunk at all.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got to get home right now. Hazel thinks I’m still in Havre. ;

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Maybe you are. Maybe we’re all in Havre. What‘s her name? . George looks and sees a WOMAN looking out Shermari’s cabi window. SHERMAN ~ . Lucy. She’s a nice girl. She’s a Canadian.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: That’s probably why she likes you. Maybe she’1ll like me.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to bring her out here.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Is she going to be my present from you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman suddenly reaches through the window, catches . Claude's hair in the back and twists it. Sherman is weari a big silver and turquoise ring that digs at Claude’s sca

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: you’re not funny. You're a couple - of clucks. Sherman drags Claude out of the car. SHERMAN (CONT’D) Okay. 1/11 just break your goddamned arm. : Sherman speaks intently to Claude out of George’s earshot George looks at the motel Manager who goes back inside. Finally, Sherman turns Claude loose and walks back to the cabin. Claude comes and flounces into the open doorway of the car.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: So. Fuck hin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What’re we doing?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: I’m taking her off somewhere. He’s telling her he’s going to meet her some place later, but he isn’t. And I'm just getting rid of her. Maybe I‘ll kill her. That’s what Indians are supposed to do, right? What else is available? Sherman emerges again, walks to the car and stuffs some money into Claude’s shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: This is shut-up money. So shut up. (looks in at George) You can shut up, too, George. Go the hell home, in fact. Sherman motions toward the cabin door. The screen opens a a young woman. steps out. This is Lucy. She’s wearing sunglasses, a sundress and carrying a small suitcase. She thin and of an age that could be 15 or 25, but obviously nobody’s pushover. She comes to the car looking sullen.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: (to Lucy) So, all right now. This is Claude. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SHERMAN (CONT’D) _ He’s my son. This is his close friend, George, who’s not going with you. Claude’s going to take you to get something to eat. This is Lucy. I‘1l be back in an hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: (gruffly) Let her get in, Claude.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: She doesn’t want to go with us.

dialogues.speaker: _ SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, she does. Sherman takes Claude’s arm and urges him out. and iooks in the back seat. LUcY (arrogantly) I’m not getting in that back seat. There isn’t any seat back there.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Let her in front.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Get in the front. Watch out. Lucy leans Claude reluctantly gets all the way out and Lucy crawls i the middle of the seat, putting her suitcase Lucy (smiles at George) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t cause me any fucking trouble, or 1/11 break you up. in the back. He turns immediately and starts back toward the cabin. Claude gets in the car and the three of them sit in the front seat without speaking. Lucy I’m hungry. Spend some of that money on me. Be a big shot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: {still furious) I don’t give a shit if you’re hungry. Lucy . You're a real odd match for father and son. You don’t look like each other.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Who do I look like? Lucy Some Greek. Maybe your mother.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Where’s she now? My mother. Lucy Wherever you live. At home, I guess. You want me to guess?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: (darkly) No. She’s dead. Are those my father’s glasses? wmucy He gave them to me. If that was your father. Do you want them back? i

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you divorced? Lucy . I’m not old enough. I’m not even married. ,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How old are you? Locy Twenty. Sixteen. How do they sound? You might be criminals. (smiles at George) How old do I look?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Eight. Or maybe a hundred. Lucy Let’s eat something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Claude jumps on the motor, spewing gravel all the way out the parking lot and whirling off toward town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy removes her sunglasses for the first time. She reach and turns on the radio, stares imperturbably at Claude an George. MUSAK commences in the form of The Ray Coniff Cho singing "April in Paris". Claude turns the radio up full blast and drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Claude’s car makes a run through Sunburst and past the Polar Bar, Jack is walking across Main Street, weaving ve slightly, heading toward his truck. He recognizes Claude’ car and waves them down and comes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What’d you rob?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You robbed something. You've taken on.a new accomplice. GEORGE . We're going to ride down to Great Falls.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're not. You’re coming home with me. We've got some ducks to clean. George looks at Lucy and at Claude. He wants to stay, but lacks the choice. He pops the door open, climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Okay. Lucy (flirting) We'll miss you. Lucy slides over to occupy George’s empty space by the window. Claude is silent, staring ahead. : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il 12

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Come on, son. You don’t know what I’m saving you from. Locy Yes he does. She pulls the door closed. Claude revs the Chevy again an heads off out of town, into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the drive home, George drives and Jack drinks out of h own pint bottle from under the seat. He and George both take a drink. Jack is somber, unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who’s that with Claude? You two into some trouble?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing Claude can’t handle. They drive.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (wearily) Boy-oh-boy. You know, Georgie, your George takes a drink, then holds the whiske! letting it trickle hotly down his throat. mother said something to me once I’ve never forgotten. She said, "Nobody dies of a broken heart." This was somewhat before you were born. We were living down in Casper still then. We’d had some big blow- up, and that was the idea she had. I don’t know why. I don’t know why I thought of it. (shakes his head, drinks) Have a drink, son. Something oughta be good in life. bottle back. JACK (CONT’D) What do you worry about, George? Do you worry about giris? Do you worry about your future sex life? Is that some of it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don’t worry about that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y in his mouth, George hands the 11. 11 12  12 13 12.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, what then? What else is there? George sits up straight and enfolds the steering wheel in his arms. -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I worry if you’re going to die pefore I do. Or if mother is. That worries me, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: If I were you I’d@ worry we might not. Things pass too fast in your life, George. Don’t worry about that. (a beat) Just stop here. Just a second. Just stop. George slows the truck, then stops in the road between wh fields. He cuts the lights and the engine. Jack rolls dow his window and puts his face out, listening. - JACK (CONT’D) I just want to listen now, George. Just listen. I don’t know. You have to do that. I like that. Jack listens. George tries to listen without knowing what he’s listening to. Jack is just gathering himself for whatever’s next. TACK (CONT’D) . (suddenly satisfied) Let's go. Let’s go home the back way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive on toward home from the alternate direction. Sitting in the field beyond the windbreak olive trees is unidentified car. A Pontiac hardtop.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well. There’s a car. Isn’t it? They drive into the house yard. The house is a prairie farmhouse, white-frame and dormered, with a front porch. MAJOR, a black Labrador retriever, walks out of the Quons barn and stands in the headlights. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack is clearly suspicious, as though he’s known what to suspicious about before now. George is nervous. SACK (CONT’D) Let's see what’s happening here. Jack opens the car door and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Jack enter from the mud-room steps. A tall, young man, WOODY, who is maybe 29, stands behind the kitc table. He’s dressed nicely in beige, pleated pants and a floral shirt with the short sleeves neatly rolled, partly disclosing a tattoo. He has wavy blond hair combed back o the sides. Woody is a stranger and seems not intended to found. Woody keeps his eyes on Jack. A glass of whiskey sits on the table. Jack looks around the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (flatly, but charged) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (edgy, but unafraid) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What‘s your name? WwooDY Woody.

dialogues.speaker: SACK
dialogues.text: (seemingly amused) Woody. Where’s Aileen--I mean-- where’s Mrs. Russell, Woody? I - guess you aren’t robbing my house, are you?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No. (a beat) Upstairs. I think she went upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (smiles) : Good. That’s a good place. Jack walks toward the stairs, which are in the hali, then turns to George. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Georgie, you and Woody step outside and wait on me. Just stay there and I’1l come out. A phone begins to RING. - AILEEN (0.8. Who's that? ( ?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s me. It’s Jack. He disappears up the stairs to confront his wife as the phone.continues to ring. George stares at the phone, whic is on a table beside the stairs. He seems to want to answ it, but does not.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Let’s just go outside. wooDY All right. They step toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Woody step outside into the car yard and stand waiting beside the house. Woody shuffles foot-to-foot. It isn’t at all clear why he doesn’t leave while he has the chance. Though he’s a nullity--his effect on the world is only chaotic and his behavior random. Woody smokes a cigarette as they stand, and it’s not possible to see tha he’s wearing cheap black and white shoes.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I like it out here. Nothing to bother you. I bet you could see Chicago if the world was flat. The Great Plains commence here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Do you play football?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: wooDY ; I have been drinking. But I’m not drunk now.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (INSIDE)
dialogues.text: That’s a real joke! Find your : goddamned suitcase. Just find it! Inside, a drawer opens and slams shut. George looks anxiously at the house. He sees Aileen then Jack pass by the upstairs window, arguing. Woody seems not to notice. They hear a plane flying overhead.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I once passed my brother in the Los Angeles airport, you know, and didn’t even recognize him. He recognized me, though. Of course he said, “Hey, bro, are you mad at me, or what?" I wasn’t mad at him. We both had to laugh. George eyes Woody with both suspicion and interest. A pau opens. WOODY (CONT’D) Did you know your mother was married before?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, I knew that.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (smiling, knowingly) It happens to all of them, now. They can’t wait to get divorced. GEORGE . . I guess so. Jack suddenly comes out of the house with AILEEN behind h Aileen is carrying a suitcase. She is a handsome, young- looking woman, 42 years old. She stops at the top of the back steps, looking grave. Jack is coldly furious and loo shaken. He walks straight up to Woody, comes close enough for their clothing to touch. Aileen gives George a guarde half-smile.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (softly) What do -you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m in the Air Force. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Is this your day off, then?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you? Don’t you understand something? Jack takes a big revolver out of his coat pocket and puts under Woody’s chin. Woody‘s face rises, but his arms stay at his sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to do with you. I don’t have any idea. I just don’t. Jack pulls the hammer back and raises the gun higher unde Woody’s chin. For a long moment no one says a word.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (calmly, finally) Jack, let’s stop now. Let’s just stop. Jack looks into Woody’s face, his teeth gritted together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're crazy, aren’t you? You’re a goddamned crazy man. Are you in iove with her, too? Are you? Say you love her so I can blow your fucking brains in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: . WOODY
dialogues.text: All right. No. It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: . AILEEN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t love me, Jack. For God’s sake. Jack turns and glares at Aileen, keeping the gun under Woody’s chin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shouts) You’re leaving! That’s why you’re packed. Get out. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: You’re not making me leave, sweetheart. I’m just leaving. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Fawn Page seus ue 17 AILEEN (CONT'D) 1d George has to be at work in the morning. She mouths silently, but very intently to George:

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: You do what your father tells you to. Aileen walks off the steps, rounds the corner of the hous and disappears into the ark. Woody’s car door opens and shuts audibly. Jack returns his attention to Woody.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’d like to think of some way to hurt you. I feel helpless about it. (pause) You think I’m a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where are you from? wooDy Chicago. A suburb of there.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (intensely) Are your parents alive? Jack pushes the gun harder under Woody’s chin.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Toe bad they have to know what you are. I bet they both wish you were dead, though...Somebody else’1l have to kill you. I don’t want to have to think about you. (lowers the gun) I guess that’s it. Jack just stands perfectly still in front of Woody, the g at his side. Woody says nothing. He waits an awful moment then steps back, looks at George, then quickly follows wh Aileen has gone. Jack looks at George helplessly. JACK (CONT’D) Does this seem stupid to you? All this yelling and going nuts? I wouldn’t blame you. You shouldn’t even see this. I don’t know what to do now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) It’1l be all right. George walks out to the road. He stands, watching Woody back the car out of the field. The car stops a moment whi Woody and Aileen sit in the car seat and have an animated conversation George can’t hear. It is only clear they aren’t arguing. When the car moves off, Aileen turns and waves at him through the back window, then Woody drives a down the road into the cold night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack has mixed himself a drink and now furiously puts together sandwiches for the both of them. He’s on the edg and trying to stay sane. The pistol is lying on the table George puts it into a kitchen drawer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You could’ve been more limited, Maybe. Maybe you shouldn’t have had her leave.

dialogues.speaker: . JACK
dialogues.text: That’s one version. Okay. That was a mistake. She should still be here, I guess. This is not her usual,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You could probably go find ner. We could do that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Where would you lock?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe in the café..

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That’s probably exactly where she is or will be soon. I think I/11 eat first, though, if that’s okay? I made your dinner here. Do you want to eat?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’1l eat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (unexpectedly) Wait a minute. Wash your hands first. You’ve got dirt on your hands. I’m your father, I oughta be able to do something for you. - Shouldn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure. Jack moves George by his shirt sleeve to the old-fashione high~faucet sink, turns on the hot tap, pushes George’s hands under and begins to soap them fiercely. George flinches from the. painful water, but his father’s hands in it, too, and he submits.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Harsh words are all alike, George. You can make ‘em up. They all mean the same thing.

George watches her sleep for a long moment, then gets up, restless, gazes out the door, then goes to find a phone book in a drawer and look up a number. Silently he decides not to call for fear of waking Lucy. But he takes the book, opened to the Casper city map, and quietly slips out of the room.

The Man takes a piece of paper from his pocket and reaches for the phone. He turns and looks aggressively at George as George passes. George, unsettled, looks away an speeds his walk.

Sudy’s house has a wheelchair ramp up to the front porch. George parks and goes to the door. 40 EXT. JUDY AND HARLEY’S HOUSE - DAY ~ 40 JUDY opens the front door smiling, not recognizing George She is near Aileen’s age but pretty and appealing in a somewhat more wholesome way-

Judy and Harl seem a more dependable, more affectionate couple than George’s parents.

Military rifles, hunting rifles with scopes, a machine gu sawed-offs with pistol grips,“ pistols of all kinds displayed. HARLEY (CONT’D) i (boasting) Starlight. Light you up after dark. George looks at Harley, then at the gun. Harley cuts his eyes at George, smiling. HARLEY (CONT‘D) I’m a civil engineer. Did you know that? .

dialogues.text: sure. (CONTINUED)

The Trails End is a cowboy-and-roughneck bar with poker and keno tab popping, people dancing and in the large back room a pitiful, small-time "Tough-Guy Contest," using a crude fi ring, shallow makeshift ceiling lights and a sparse, drun crowd in attendance--vaguely interested COWBOYS, INDIANS their GIRLFRIENDS. Two INDIAN BOYS spar but no one in the audience pays much attention; some are booing and tauntin the boxers. The Indians are bloodying each other almost without effort. George is remotely cocky. Lucy is half-drunk and ill- tempered from the strain of the previous days and from he responsibilities. i

VISITOR’S WAITING AREA > DAY Interior room has windows all around, a table and two chairs. George looks in through the window. He can hear nothing. Lucy waves at him through the panes. He waves back. Just then, JOHNNY enters with a male DEPUTY and is told t sit. He’s wearing an ill-fitting orange jail jumpsuit and tennis shoes. Lucy hugs him, then they both sit. Johnny is 25, fresh-faced, blond and pretty with an arresting, cold malevolence only a sister could ignore. H sits at the table, folds his hands tensely, expectantly. glances out the window at George, who’s trying not to he conspicuous, while realizing he’s in view. George reads their lips: (CONTINUED)

George, disturbed, turns away awkwardly, then walks to a more hidden position from where he can watch Lucy’s and Johnny’s intense discussion. A phone is beside him. On impulse he dials home.

dialogues.text: LucY (sweetly) Who to? You? George is frantic but attempting to appear calm. He tries to take off his own jacket and can actually slip it off h arm and onto hers so that it covers her. He’s left with a flannel shirt. Lucy seems at one moment relatively clear- headed, the next, confused. .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. To somebody else...Do you think I’m pretty handsome? Lucy (fatigued) You might become handsome. I don’t know. (draws closer) Oh, I’m so cold now. Your coat doesn’t help much. She is becoming light-headed again. LUCY (CONT’D) My head feels zizzy. You‘re supposed to get out of bad things, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Lucy . If I’d known Johnny had killed somebody I would’ve never come down here. The fucker...I wish I was older.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (holding her closer) It/’ll be all right. Lucy {pause} You could tell me some dream of yours. I feel like hearing a dream all of a sudden. Maybe I’m short of sleep. That‘’d be nice. Do you remember one?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (musing) Yes, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lucy Which way’s north now? I like to stay oriented. Lucy tries to look around, though she’s losing her streng George motions with his head toward the desert clothed in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s that way. ' Lucy I'll never get Dack tnere. (rests, close to him) What was your dream, Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was when we were driving down here. Lucy Wait. Lie on top of me, baby. Make me warmer. George negotiates himself sideways so that he can move on top of her, his face near hers, his lips close to her ear LUCY (CONT’D) Oh, that’s good. I’m fine now. George turns his head so he can look down at the glitteri city.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In this dream I was driving down some highway and it was snowing. And off the road there was a wrecked car on fire. And inside, in the flames, were these people. I could see them in the windows, trying to get out. But they were trapped. And I stopped and ran up, and I pulled the door and pulled it and pulled it until it opened, but it was hot and smokey inside. And I reached and grabbed inside and I felt all their hands. First, an adult’s hands and then children’s. And I took them all out until they were all out in the dark beside the highway. Safe. And I just stood (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GEORGE (CONT’D) there beside that burning car then, and nobody talked. But I was their hero. Lucy has fallen asleep close to him. > GEORGE (CONT’D) (imploring) Don’t go to sleep. That’s a mistake. There’s more in this dream... George shakes her, then slaps her cheeks softly with his injured hand, trying to keep her alert. Lucy (feebly) That’s a sweet dream. You’re the hero. Your conscience is clear, isn’t it? She dozes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no, don’t go to sleep. I shouldn’t have told that to you. -I‘m sorry. Lucy (drifting off) I’m blue. I must be blue. I feel blue. Goodness. She passes into sleep.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (faintly) . Don’t sleep. I could marry you. I could. He desperately shakes her and simultaneously tries to cov her with his body, finally embraces her when she doesn’t respond. She is in shock. The rain and wind swirl around then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the moment before the first light of dawn. The ligh (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ef Casper still twinkle. A pair of car lights moves up th road. For a time it’s not clear that Art has not come bac though as the lights come nearer the car grows visible as reservation police car on a night patrol. When the car nears the oil rig, it stops. A POLICEMAN runs his flashlight across the well platform, disclosing Lucy and George, who seem asleep where they’ve been handcuffed and are covered with dirt and frost. When they reach George o of the Indian policemen squats, brushes frost off George' face.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: What are you two doing here? He shakes George, who wakes to the light in his face and faraway sound of the Indian’s voice. Lucy remains still beneath him, almost unnoticeable. The policeman holds his finger to Lucy’s neck, but there’s no pulse.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: {to his partner) Not this one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (faint, desperate) I have the right key. She made a mistake. You can have it now. In an instant, George recollects himself, tries to lift himself off Lucy, turns his face to hers and sees she’s d of shock and concussion during the night.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. CASPER SHERIFF’S OFFICE - MORNING It is several days later. George, his face bruised, sits beside an empty detective’s desk in a large room Where 3 other sheriff’s detectives are working at their desks, talking on phones. They ignore him. A fourth DETECTIVE casually enters from another office carrying a metal container, which he sets on his desk and from which he produces George’s wallet, some change, a clasp knife and locker key from the Greyhound depot. George picks up his belongings with his bandaged hand and stuffs them in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) You’ve had a time, haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The detective puts up his feet and pulls his pants legs u over his boot tops, revealing the butt of a pistol in one boot.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What else you got in mind? :

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do about her brother?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Don’t think about that boy now. He’s in another world from you. (a beat) Tell me something else you got on your mind.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (mutedly) Go home. I guess I’11 go home.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (smiling, leaning in his swivel chair) You done enough damage, you figure? Had enough fun?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’ve done enough.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You couldn’t have stood much more fun, could you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (looks up malevolently) That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (arrogantly) What else?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing. After a pause, the detective nods.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Then let ‘er rip, I guess, son. In the event we locate Mr. Falcone and Miss Bennett, how easy is it to find you to get you to testify? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sunburst, Montana.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Pretty easy. There’s a lady outside to give you a ride. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George eats a burger and drinks a milkshake. Judy eats nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I never reached your dad.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He’s probably working.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He probably is. But you oughta go home. You could go in the wrong direction pretty easily now. (a beat) It may not seem like it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t exactly seem like it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (smiley) Well. Whatever's right. {a beat) I haven’t wanted to ask you a whole lot of questions. You could‘ve called me quicker. I could have got you out of juvenile home. I’m your next of kin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That poor girl, though. I'd like to ask you how you got with her. And that other man, that man in the hole. And those other two people? How’d you get in with them? You could’ve gotten killed out there. You know that? You wouldn’t have been the first. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is scolding now. Something that’s happened to George frightens her but also has pricked her curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (staring out) I guess so. - He is silent for a few seconds, as if the question has no place in his thinking, nor the answer any relevance. GEORGE (CONT’D) Luck, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Not luck I’d want.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bad luck. “Judy looks at him uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (with distaste) Aileen wants her car back, George. George looks at her, emerging out of his preoccupation at the sound of his mother’s name.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where’s she?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) She called from down in Rock Springs. I don’t really know the particulars. She wanted me to wire her some money. Which I did. But of course I told her about you. And she said she wanted to see you, said she’d take the bus up here. She’s afraid you’/re mad at her. I told her you’d been through a patch down here. It wasn’t a real nice chat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: She was real interested about her car, too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s her car... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GEORGE (CONT’D) (a beat) Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: out at the Tropicana Motel, like a you’re coming in from Natrona, room 242. She called last night from there. She sounded all right. I don’t know _ what to tell you, George. She’s your mother.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to take me home now. Just leave me sittin’ here and goon. I‘1l call somebody. Harl’s nuts today. I may have to leave myself pretty soon. I can’t always take it even though I love hin. (laughs humorlessly) That’s catchin’, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I guess so. Judy leans across the table and hugs him and kisses him o the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes directly to the locker. He opens it and there is the envelope with the $3,000, just as he and Lucy had left it. He pockets the money and walks out. EXT./INT. DRIVING THROUGH CASPER “80. George drives toward the western outskirts of Casper, ‘He drives until he sees a yellow fotel, turning in and d to the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks along the 2nd level of motel rooms, looks in one screen, sees a man lying on a bed asleep, then walks until he reaches room 242. He sees Aileen through the win she notices him. She finally does, comes to the door. INT. AILEEN’S MOTEL ROOM - MORNING 83 Aileen is in stocking feet, wearing blue jeans, her hair tied back as though it was dirty. She turns in the middle of the small room and smiles at him. Her suitcase is open on the floor beside the bed. Some folded clothes are on t unmade covers. She is packing and unrepentant but wishes, if possible, still to be his mother.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Come in, George. It’s ‘the height of “ grandeur in here, isn’t it? I was just trying to put some order on things. Aileen looks around the room. The bathroom door is open a the light on. - She goes over and closes it, then sits on bed. AILEEN (CONT’D) Privacy can be your burden sometimes. (a beat) Looks like somebody whacked your cheek.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They did.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: We can talk about all that business if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We don’t have to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee be  83

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: I’m interested.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s not very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Have you been trying to find me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN -
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) That’s good. I just took a flyer. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (a beat) Where’s Woody?

dialogues.speaker: . AILEEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Woody. She clears her throat and begins to put on a pair of high heeled shoes. AILEEN (CONT’D) Woody decided to leave the Air Force early. But they came and took him back. I didn’t see any future in that for me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (watching her) I guess not. Aileen finishes with her shoes and smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Have you got a compliment for your oid mom? I/d like one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (reluctant) - You look pretty. I’m glad to see you. Aileen takes a piece of folded clothing from beside her a lays it in her bag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: That‘’s a nice one. I’m glad to see you, toc. (a beat) Would you like to go have lunch?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, thanks. She smiles at him in acknowledgment, then reaches to the night table, takes a tissue out of a small package and bl her nose. She’s not crying, only at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Sometimes, you know, I/11 think about something I did. Just something. Years ago. Or last week even. And it’s as if I’d read it. Isn’t that strange?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Maybe that’s not so bad, finally, maybe it’s a disease I have. You think I‘1l get well?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (smiling) I don’t know. Maybe. I hope so. 1

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sit down? George sits in the little writing-desk chair, facing her. AILEEN (CONT’D) (smiles) How’s my beautiful car holding up? Did you drive it? She stands, walks to the window and looks out. She can se her car in the lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s fine. It could use an accelerator pedal spring is all. You can have it back.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: {turns to face him) Maybe I will. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AILEEN (CONT’D) (a beat) Georgie, I’m not very good at sharing things right now. I’m sorry. I‘’1l answer anything you'd like to ask me. Whether I even want to or not. You don’t have to trust me. We/’re both grown-ups.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Were you ever married before?

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (indignant) Who told you that? That isn’t true. Did Jack say that to you? That’s an awful thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sheepish) He didn’t say it. Woody did it. I just wanted to know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (packing) Woody. How wonderful. Not that it matters. When I married your father I thought he'd take me out of the sticks. And that is not exactly what happened. So. I/’d like a less domestic life for a while. That‘s all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I understand that.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (sweetly) De you think you understand women? Have you had some experience with women?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sort of. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (resigned) Sort of’s enough. Your life’s your own business, sweetheart. Sometimes it scares you to death, it’s so much your own business, you just want to run. You know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't. But I do now.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (good-humored) Do you want me to go home with you? Is that what you'd like?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you want to?

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Well, no. I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well. Then. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: You're not exactly like your * father, are you? *

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (confidently) * No. *

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Okay. We're on our own in this,right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right, we are. *

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (smiles sadly) You can't fix people. (pause) Let's get out of here. This place gives me the willies. They exit the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘George and Aileen walk toward her car, George carrying h

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: Where'm I taking you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bus station. (a beat) Where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: (light-hearted) I don't know. Florida? Get a tan. Maybe I could go to college. Who knows? You wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: I don't blame you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've got some money. DO you want some of it?

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: How much have you got?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A thousand dollars. George stops, takes the money from his pocket, hands it t

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: I don't know where you got it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here. It's great. I worked for it. They resume walking to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aileen drives, George rides. They are released from’ some pressure. They arrive at the Greyhound station. Aileen stops outside.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: {smiles, embarrassed) So. I'm forty-two years old. This is where I am at this point. George reaches and takes the photograph from under the vi holds it without looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's just something I want. AILEEN . Oh,right. That's for you. You keep that. We'll look at it someday and laugh about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George opens the door to get out.

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: I want you to have a good life. Give me a hug. I/’11 see you again. That’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay. They embrace in the front seat. Tears are in Aileen’s eye

dialogues.speaker: AILEEN
dialogues.text: I’ve got a knot in my stomach, of all things. Isn‘t that odd? George gets out, closes the door. Aileen drives away, leaving George standing alone, watching her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes to the ticket desk, looks beyond the ticket AGENT, reads the departures and arrivals. He looks at the clock, sees it is 2:00 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When’s the next bus going to San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (routinely, reads from a sheet) Ten o’clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How about north? _ The agent rubs his eyes and looks at the board.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (vaguely sarcastic) North. Like to Canada?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (reacts to mention of Canada) Beat. : * No. To Montana. Great Falls.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (bored) Billings, Bozeman, Butte, Helena, Great Falls. Five-eighteen. George looks at the board again, considers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay. Great Falls. He pays for a ticket using the money Lucy left and puts i in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George makes a collect call to his father, who answers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (softly, close to phone) Hi, hi. It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (sternly, but relieved) Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quick1y) . Down in Wyoming. I’m in Casper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What the heli for? What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE /
dialogues.text: I’m on my way home. I/1] probably be there tomorrow. I’m on the bus. JACK (V.0.) i Where’s your mother? Are you with her?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. She‘’s not. (a beat) * I saw her. She got back her car.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (sullenly) She’ll need it. Does she think she’s coming back?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. Not right away.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: XI don’t get any of this. I don’t get any-of it. You know what I mean? I don’t. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I know. Ill be home tomorrow afternoon. Okay? JACK (V.0.) . Sure. Why not? Come home. That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I’ll see you. JACK (V.0. I‘ll see you. They hang up.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 88
dialogues.text: George takes a seat to begin his 3-hour wait for the bus home. The effects of the last few days have settled on hi and he is abstracted and undirected. He unwraps the banda on his hand and exercises his fingers painfully. He throw the bandage away. He’s incapable of relaxing or sitting still and begins to wander around the bus station. As he does, time seems to fracture. He passes people randomly, overhearing conversations, becoming indistinguishable within the populated depot.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEARD
dialogues.text: I went out there in the night where he was changing his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEARD
dialogues.text: I wondered if the FBI would be calling my house. He stares at soldiers and Indians, farmers, old men and backpackers, fixating on an idle gesture or on someone‘’s shoes. He’s becoming more abstracted.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEARD
dialogues.text: I thought he wanted me, you know. But when he started he just lost his heart. He plays pinball.- He goes into the little diner, drinks Coke and watches the fry-cook. For brief moments time see to slow down, the sounds blurring. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Two girls, early twenties, stand in front of an open lock One vaguely resembles Lucy, changes her blouse while the other girl shields her. George watches, transfixed, standing against a column. He is remembering Lucy. A man walks past where George is standing. He is a large, pulky man in his fifties, wearing extremely handsome west clothes: snake-skin boots, whipcord trousers, a silver rodeo buckle belt, white shirt and hat and a fleece-lined denim jacket. He is carrying a hard-sided attache case an a wrapped package, which he delivers to the ticket counte for express service. It is the man George had seen making call outside the Eden Isle motel days before. The man has noticed George and walks over, surprising George out of h reverie.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (amiable but businesslike) Did you ever find any work? I saw you at the motel.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t looking for work. MAN . You seeing your family here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.”

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Buses never go anyplace particularly good, do they?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sometimes they do. MAN . Where’s yours going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Where’s home?

dialogues.speaker: . __ GEORGE
dialogues.text: Broadview; Montana.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What do-you do there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (suspicious) I live there.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You broke?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (uninterested) - No.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (accusing) You look broke.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Looks lie, then. The man smiles at George as if to dismiss him and leave. GEORGE (CONT’D) (idly) You still passing out jobs on the street?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (casually) Why, did you decide you wanted to earn a lot of money?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Working. That‘’s the only way to make money, unless you steal it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Working doing what?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Working the oil fields up in Gillette. Roughneck work.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where’s that at?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It’s a long way from here. A half day’s drive in a car. Twenty years on the bus. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: immediate 105. 88

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (idly) How would I get there if I wanted a job?

dialogues.speaker: MAN -
dialogues.text: I’d take you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I don’t know anything about that kind of work.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well. You’d just have to learn then. You ever learned anything before?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (getting the point) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You get along with your parents okay?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: They busted up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, they’re not busted up. They’re at home.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand? - The man reaches and takes George’s red, scratched hand an looks at it. .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
